comment: Only time I would drink this is with coke...which is never
Nose is  soft, almost no aroma. Hints of sweet rye or leather.   Bitter  and  sweet and spicy.   This spirit is better over ice or mixed.
Real simple taste. Nothing really to write home about. This is my well Whisky and I'll usually have it with cola if I want a quick drink.
A fairly bland whiskey with sweet taste. If you enjoy a sweet Canadian whiskey I would go Crown Royal. This whiskey is good for mixing with cola, but it's not going to impress anyone.
Nothing to special about this one.  I will drink if deciding to have a mixed drink.  A little too sweet and taste of vanilla.
My first bottle. I can vaguely smell a little vanilla, but there's not much aroma to it. Taste seems very bland.
Not recommended for straightforward sipping. Actually, it doesn't taste like it was meant for it; flavours of simple syrup and ginger ale are predominant. Not even a pinch of spice. So dull!
Mixer of champions at such a cheap price. Biased because this is my "honetown" distillery
Canadian club + ginger ale + lime = summer. What I go for if its been a long hot day

Let's face it, I buy this cuz I can get a handle for $16 and it's just fine in a whisky sour. I started drinking it with a cube or two and actually enjoy it, there is some caramel/toffee thing going on that is really good.
Favorite mixing Canadian whisky, not overly sweet.
Iconic Canadian whisky. A bit of a dryness to it. In my opinion, best used as a base to a mixed drink i.e. gingerale
Dégusté pour la première fois à La Ferme à Charlevoix, dans une bouteille format échantillon. Whisky très ordinaire, à garder pour la mixologie.
I had fond memories of this being one of the first whiskies I ever tried. Sadly a revisit found a strange astringent taste dominating the palate.
This whiskey is about the best value whiskey there is. Very inexpensive and easy to drink on the rocks daily.
Good for mixing, but flavour disappears pretty quick.  Refreshing with ginger ale.
Not one to drink by itself.

Given the cases of this stuff that Don Draper consumed over the course of the hit show Mad Men, you would have to conclude that it wasn't only people's fashion sense that was much better back then.  A weird and unpleasant plastic note dominates the nose and utterly smothers phantom caramel notes that you can pick out if you really work at it... but really, why would you want to work at it?  Stiffly synthetic vanilla assaults your palate and the bummer finish has a drying bitterness about it.  On the rocks, Canadian Club is magically transformed from poor whiskey into acrid water.  Strictly a mixer folks! Note: My rating is for drinking this neat or on the rocks.  Add another star if you're planning on mixing this with Ginger Ale.
Worst whiskey I have ever drank and threw out

Okay, so I saw this at a wedding reception this evening where the choices were limited. I thought, "well Don Draper swills this relentlessly on Mad Men" so how bad could it be?  I had it on the rocks. On nosing, I couldn't detect a whole lot except alcohol. On the palate, more of the same, to the point where I almost thought I was drinking sweetened vodka. After a while, a little caramel came through, almost making think I was drinking rum. This is not anything I would buy a bottle of, or drink on the rocks again, but I thought I'd try it. I'm sure it would mix well, as it didn't have anything offensive.

It's OK... Probably the best Canadian whisky I've had so far (excluding that sortilège by Mondia Alliance... so yummy). It's almost impossible to find decent Canadian whisky in France sadly. (I got to try Crown Royal later... And I'm hoping to try Glen Breton next)
A working horse whisky, perfect for cocktails. While it does lack complexity and standout flavours, to its credit it also lacks anything offputting.

The nose is sharp and a bit off. Basically smells like ethanol and nuts. The taste is very sweet and borderline unpleasant. The finish is disappointing and drys out your mouth. The price is great, but that is about all this has going for it.
Just too many bad memories of this to give it any praise
Not much flavor. Had on rocks so might have diluted.

2.6. Was raised on this... My Step Dad drank it  every day.  Sometimes I would take a sip, especially when people brought over other whiskeys or bourbons, and I always compared the taste...   Canadian Club is underrated.  Evan Williams Black, Wild Turkey , etc.. have more oomph in flavors, but Canadian Club is beautiful for what it is.

Somewhat floral on the nose, with faint notes of cereal and spice on the palate. Otherwise, this is predominantly sweet. It is far from extravagant, but does not pretend to be either. Priced under $25 CAD, it is a solid choice for highballs and mixed drinks.

Vanilla & spicy
Nose, sweet, light scent
Mouth feel, sweet, light, apple
Finish, warm, easy drinking. Best w one cube of ice
I just had a bad opinion of that whisky... But I bought a bottle to give it a chance... And I still have a bad opinion of this whisky... OK in a cocktail but nothing more... Awful finale...

Barreled transfer from November 2016


Regardless of the "Premium Extra Aged" label, this is the regular base level Canadian Club. 

This is a blended Canadian whisky with no age statement. It has a dark amber color that appears to be heavy with added colorant. It no doubt is chill filtered and comes in at the legal minimum 40% ABV. 

The nose is harsh and immature. There is an initial blast of fennel that fades to overly sweet. Pancake syrup, butterscotch, oaky vanilla, toffee and caramel. There is also some honey. The sweetness screams inevitable hangover. 

The palate is overly sweet as well. Heavy butterscotch and syrup. Not very complex at all. There is also a metallic taste that again tells its lack of maturity. 

The mouthfeel is slightly oily, not bad. 

The finish is medium length and very sweet with a mild spice. 

This is definitely a mixing whisky and not meant to be consumed neat. The value is one of its only great qualities. I bought a 200mL bottle for the whopping price of $3.48 before taxes. Can't really knock that. If you are looking for a cheap mixer, this will do the job nicely. 2.25
If you are a fan of Canadian Club I urge you to try Forty Creek. It's like a small batch, craft version of CC. Much better quality and still very affordable.

I’ve tried this whisky on the rocks and used it as a mixer. You really can’t go wrong for the value here. The palate is sweet but I don’t find it overly sweet. Flavours of vanilla, some spice and a bit of charred oak will hit you subtly and then taper off quickly with a creamy finish. I find this to be a very inoffensive whisky and although it’s not very complex it is a great whisky to have around for an occasional drink.
Nope, nope, nope. Yuck. It's just nasty, I can't even explain it.
Pretty good nothing special but nothing bad. Smooth.

Easy drinking Canadian whisky. Sweet vanilla, Christmas fruit cake but not to sweet. The rye gives it a spiciness and back bone. Not great sipper, but has enough for on the rocks or a nice Manhattan. What more do you want from a $12 whisky.

came in with low expectations, but was pleasantly surprised. the nose is bad, just heavy ethanol burn. palate is sweet honey, grain alcohol, and reminds me a bit of a cheap blended scotch. I can sip this neat and be happy if this is the best option available. 80/100
Plastic cork. It is not good.

Rather than a "good" whiskey this is a "good" example of a standard Canadian whiskey that shouldn't be disparaged or lauded for being something it is not.  CC is both a standard and standby and for many of us an "old" standby at that, in that plenty of people drink it so its always around, and for some reason thats important. It's the "Being There" factor of knowing what you have and get with CC It just pulls it's weight as a lower priced "drinker" by being mixable with soda or water and a twist and being a completely unmemorable drink, and that's not always a bad thing either.  For those who have been disgusted by some really bad bourbons and whiskeys, the JR something er others and Lazy hillbilly Guy and what nots of really terrible whiskies, well, this is certianly NOT one of those.   It doesn't suck, it just isn't ever going to win an award unless its a contest for being ordinary.
    
    I've often wondered if perhaps Canadian corn is simply inferior to that of the states in sweetness and flavor values for fermentation, it could explain a lot about the "Canadians" in general,  but either way the "corn" factor in this one is just not enough to even be worth mentioning.  In fact it stands out as a "Canadian" whiskey in that it offers nothing special in really any category of flavor components, but also has nothing offensive to offer either.  In every way it seems an industry standard  for what passes as lower-mid shelf store product found anywhere that is just "good enough" for every day use but only in an "ordinary" sense of the term.  There are plenty worse examples of the genre when it comes to Canadians and certianly some better ones also,  standard CC just falls smack in the "white label" middle of plainess.  In a pinch if theres nothing better, then this will do as long as you keep expectations low.  Just remember to take Pamela Anderson with you to the ice fishing shack and you won't care how really ordinary this whiskey is, 'old standby" will be ready to not interfere with Pam er um fishing..
Not too deep, but well balanced taste. Can definitely taste the alcohol
so far my favorite to mix with coke, dr pepper or 7up

Great to start with.
It’s smooth, sweet and goes great mixed with cola or dry
Smooth and spicy, with a little  biterness. The taste is close to a rhum.
Bottle was in a cellar since 1970
Std taste, good value for the money!

It's good with couple cubes of ice, or water. It's not good neat. 
I would give it a 2.5.
Decent quality for the price, making for an overall good value

Defines tasty bang for smooth finished buck in the usa, and if you mix many drops w a good value bourbon (EW, Benchmark) you have just upped the latter to major sippability. (Do not ever tell anyone you did this, tho.)
Vanilla, maple, mellow and very light. It has a hint of rum.
Ej värst sensationell. Lite kryddig ton, lite vaniljton. Riv. Tja!

In my venture to try Canadian whiskies, this one was not my favorite. Not my least favorite. Canadian Hunter takes that one. It's not even on Distiller if that tells you anything. But Canadian Club is much better. Just not at all the best out there.
Sweet with Carmel and vanilla flavors as well as some wood. Very subtle. Not at all interesting but very smooth and easy drinking
Very bland. Only use as a mixer.
All rounder. Not too harsh on the rocks or flask - can’t go past pre-mixed CC & Dry
Wouldn’t wish it on my worst enemy.
Cheap but tastes a little like bug spray. Side note from wife- he drinks it weekly Boom!

For a cheaper whisky this is not bad! Huge caramel notes with a touch of the spiciness. You do get a bit of the alcoholic burn that often comes with a cheaper spirit (you can tell they are rather loose with the heads and tails), but it is really not bad for the price. Throw in a cube or two and this is not bad at all. Once again, price is the key here... For $12 a fifth this is well worth it. I've certainly spent more on worse.

Appearance: So the color I found in this prohibition superhero is burnished bronze. It’s legs on the inside of the glass are medium thin and oily.

Nose: After bringing it up for a whiff I found the sweet nose with notes of caramel, pancakes and syrup, basil, oak, orange rind, honey, and saw dust.

Taste: On the palate I found notes of salted almonds, vanilla latte, honey, and cantaloupe and honeydew melons. 

Finish: The finish was a bit sharp, but that faded quickly into a honeyed aftertaste.

Thoughts: This Canadian whisky is a top seller; if memory serves, only Crown Royal sells more whisky than Club. With its bottom shelf price tag I wasn't expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. In fact, I liked it better than the more expensive Crown. I had no problems drinking it neat, and wouldn't mind getting this again or trying one of Club’s other family members. Thank you friends, I'm happy to join the Club! Cheers!
For a whisky this cheap, this is a very smooth and approachable one. It offers a good casual drink.
Kind of a cherry medicine flavor. Better  than Canadian Mist
Everyday sipper to feel like Don

Nose: Wet brown cardboard boxes. Plywood sawdust. Grass clippings. A tiny trace of vanilla and aniseed, some grainy ethanol and a whiff of fly spray. Very faint overall – there is virtually no nose.

Palate: Light, nondescript arrival with some miniscule brown sugar notes. There is no development. The texture is less dense than water.

Finish: Very short. There is no finish other than a mild soapy ethanol note, which leaves a trace sweetness in the mouth.

This is unbelievably thin, watery and gutless – it’s like drinking a dilute shot of vodka to which a few drops of whisky have been added. The only complimentary thing I can say is that it is so lacking in personality that it even lacks offensive notes, so on that basis I’m giving it 1 star.

It’s not the worst whiskey I’ve ever tasted – far from it – but it is without question the most anaemic. As a mixer all it adds is a vague suggestion of “brown spirit”.

“Inferior” : 1 star
Not bad for its price. I mean, how much can one expect from a under 15$ whiskey really! :) But I would have it as a everyday drink.

So its been a long time since I had any Canadian whisky so I thought I would try some to see where it stacks up. Expected it to be bad from memory but hey its a new day so here we go. I nosed this so many times looking for anything resembling whiskey I almost hyper- ventilated. All I get is some watered down diet ginger ale splashed with witch hazel. Oh and there is an off note too, kinda like cod liver oil. I debated even sipping it. Braved it out and got more ginger water/alcohol with some bitter oak. Finish is mercifully short, dry and bitter. I don't see how they can even call this whiskey its brown vodka. This was a 50ml for a buck........would rather lite the dollar on fire. Still have a Canadian Mist 50ml to try, that will have to be another night cant take any more. Overall I'd call it undrinkable and good luck mixing with it. 20/100 sorry if ive offended any canucks

I had a pretty good idea of what this was going to be before I bought it. I was inspired to make this purchase after watching Don Draper drink this stuff on Madmen. I figured that if he can habitually sip this for over a decade, I can get through a single bottle.

Nose: The big note is something like a Vanilla Coke or a Rootbeer float. Other than that it's dusty corn and a bit of rye spice and herb. Extremely grainy and young. Maybe a bit of orange peel. It's ever so slightly floral. Not too bad actually.

Palate: Sweetness coming in the form of corn notes, but not like a bourbon. It's really a one-note pony. It's all vanilla. Outside of that, there's a medicinal quality. Not like an Islay Scotch though. It's simply reminiscent of the aftertaste of some non-flavored syrupy medicine. Rough.

Finish: All rye spice. More vanilla, some herb, and a dash of pepper. Very boozy. Thankfully, it's over pretty quickly.

Whisky must have come a long way since the 50s. I'd expect better of a multi-millionaire like Don Draper because this is a downright uncomfortable experience. Even the Crown Royal Bourbon Mash was more tolerable and considerably more interesting.

I know I'm being harsh on something that is clearly intended to be used as a mixer. But hey. I've had much better experiences from the bottom shelf. This tasting was akin to ripping off a bandaid. I was dreading it after my first few tastes but am glad it's out of the way. It makes Johnnie Walker Red taste like a high-end blend. It was only $13, so I'm done complaining. Instead, I think I'll go brush my teeth with hydrogen peroxide and try to forget that any of this happened.

On the nose, the wood comes through first and almost in tandem with an acetone type alcohol. Faint caramel and floral scents also comes through. The body is light and has a slight coating in the mouth. On the palate I mostly get the wood from the cask with a slight spice that lingers.

During a recent stay at an all-inclusive hotel, I was met with a very limited choice of whisky options: the infamous Canadian Club, VAT69, and another blend I have never even heard of. Do I really want to review THIS bottle? Well, let's get on with it. On the nose… Hello? Anyone there? Indistinct corn sweetness, alcohol and some grassy notes - that's it. Maybe it's not as bad as I thought? I am proven wrong. Harsh and watery at the same time, this tastes like a sweetened, oak-flavored vodka. Thank God, the burning finish is short to nonexistent. Seriously, no.

RATING: 1.0/5.0 stars ≙ 48 pts → UNDRINKABLE
Light woody scent, really subtle. Smooth in mouth. Sweet and spicy. Good to try one time. But would not purchase it second time for sure.
Had it in the Schooner Bar on the Royal Caribbean Allure of the Seas.  Very good.
Multilayered, but in rather baffling than complex way. A lot can be found here, even spiciness, but mostly sweetness of burnt sugar.

Amber, fresh and clean nose.
Some hints of grassyness.
Initial honey and vanilla on the palette.
Sweet and buttery.
Turns to a very earthy and grassy taste with secondary floral notes in the finish.
Nice sweet flavor. I know its cheap but I enjoy it as a casual.

By itself: Sweet candi sugars. Inoffensive and devoid of flavor, for the most part. It's basically the perfect mixer.

With a 7.5er of Canada Dry and some ice: yep, that's the spot. This drink will be good in the summer.
I don’t care how cheap this is, it’s classic and makes a great whisky and coke.
Simple vanilla. Short sweet finish. Not horrible. Just below average
My favorite budget buy for a handle of whiskey!

After almost two weeks of absence, i can rate another whisky. This is my second Canadian Whisky, and now that i have tasted two, i can tell there is a profile that identifies canadian drams: maple syrup. 

bottled at 40%abv, this "Premium extra" whisky is rather good, specially on the nose. Tawny color, very appealing.

On the nose: Very sweet, with maple syrup, honey, vanilla, prunes and creme brulee notes. 

On the palate is sweet but also grassy, with pleasant oaky notes, oranges, with a sensation of toffee and tobacco at the same time, with a medium spicy finish. It is light bodied and after adding water the nose turns fully honeyed and the palate turns into lemon bitter notes and tobacco finish. Good average dram, very sweet.
It's just okay even for the price.
